[[File:Is Two over one Railroad Fare.jpg|thumb|250px|Triple Crossing in 1919]]
'''Triple Crossing''' in [[Richmond, Virginia]] is believed to be the only place in [[North America]] where three [[Class I railroad]]s cross at different levels at the same spot.
At the lowest (ground) level, the original [[Richmond and York River Railroad]] was extended after the [[American Civil War]] to connect with the [[Richmond and Danville Railroad]], later part of the [[Southern Railway (US)|Southern Railway]] System, currently part of [[Norfolk Southern]]. The line runs east to [[West Point, Virginia]].
The middle level was the main line of the [[Seaboard Air Line Railroad]], now part of [[CSX Transportation]] known as the "S" line, just south of [[Main Street Station (Richmond)|Main Street Station]]. It is planned to become part of the [[Southeast High Speed Rail Corridor]].
At the top level is the [[Peninsula Subdivision Trestle]], a {{Convert|3|mi|km|adj=mid|-long}} viaduct parallel to the north bank of the [[James River (Virginia)|James River]] built by the [[Chesapeake and Ohio Railway]] in 1901 to link the former [[Richmond and Allegheny Railroad]] with C&O's Peninsula Subdivision to [[Newport News, Virginia|Newport News]] and export [[coal pier]]s.
The viaduct, now owned by CSX Transportation, provided an alternate path to the notoriously unstable [[Church Hill Tunnel]] which buried a work train with fatalities on October 2, 1925. A locomotive and ten [[flat car]]s remain entombed with at least one rail worker, killing several others whose bodies were eventually recovered.
The triple crossing has been a Richmond attraction for railfans for over 100 years, although the number of photographic angles decreased in the 1990s due to a new flood wall.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Hawkins |first=Jeff |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=March 2008 |title=The Bridges of Richmond |journal=Railpace Newsmagazine |volume= |issue= |pages=47 |id= |url= |accessdate= |quote= }}</ref>
